templates.name: pfsense firewall
templates.description: based on FreeBSD template. It requires Zabbix agent 6.4 or newer.

items.name: FreeBSD: Host name of Zabbix agent running
FreeBSD: Zabbix agent ping
items.description: The agent always returns 1 for this item. It could be used in combination with nodata() for the availability check.

items.name: FreeBSD: Version of Zabbix agent running
FreeBSD: Maximum number of opened files
items.description: It could be increased by using the sysctl utility or modifying the file /etc/sysctl.conf.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Configured max number of opened files is too low on {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Maximum number of processes
items.description: It could be increased by using the sysctl utility or modifying the file /etc/sysctl.conf.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Configured max number of processes is too low on {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of waiting for I/O processes
items.description: The number of processes in a running state.

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of running processes
items.description: The number of processes in a running state.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Too many processes running on {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of sleep processes
items.description: The number of processes in a running state.

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of zombie processes
items.description: The number of processes in a running state.

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of processes
items.description: The total number of processes in any state.

items.name: FreeBSD: Processor load (1 min average)
items.description: Overall system load with all cores.

items.name: FreeBSD: Processor load (5 min average)
items.description: Overall system load with all cores.

items.name: FreeBSD: Processor load (1 min average per core)
items.description: The processor load is calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Processor load is too high on {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Processor load (5 min average per core)
items.description: The processor load is calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

items.name: FreeBSD: Processor load (15 min average per core)
items.description: The processor load is calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

items.name: FreeBSD: CPU idle time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

items.name: FreeBSD: CPU interrupt time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

items.name: FreeBSD: CPU nice time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

items.name: FreeBSD: CPU system time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

items.name: FreeBSD: CPU user time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

items.name: FreeBSD: Host name
items.description: A host name of the system.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Lack of free swap space on {HOST.NAME}
triggers.description: It probably means that the systems requires more physical memory.

items.name: FreeBSD: System information
items.description: The information as normally returned by the 'uname -a'.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Host information was changed on {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Number of logged in users
items.description: The number of users who are currently logged in.

items.name: FreeBSD: Get filesystems
items.description: The `vfs.fs.get` key acquires raw information set about the file systems. Later to be extracted by preprocessing in dependent items.

items.name: FreeBSD: Available memory
items.description: The available memory is defined as free+cached+buffers memory.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Lack of available memory on server {HOST.NAME}

items.name: FreeBSD: Percent used memory
items.description: The available memory is defined as free+cached+buffers memory.

items.name: FreeBSD: Zabbix agent availability
items.description: Monitoring the availability status of the agent.

triggers.name: FreeBSD: Zabbix agent is not available
triggers.event_name: FreeBSD: Zabbix agent is not available (for {$AGENT.TIMEOUT})
triggers.description: For passive checks only the availability of the agents and a host is used with {$AGENT.TIMEOUT} as the time threshold.

discovery_rules.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rules.description: The discovery of network interfaces as defined in the global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

trigger_prototypes.name: IPv4 local-link destination address packets detected
IPv4 local-link src address packets detected

operations.value: IPv4 local-link src address packets detected
IPv4 local-link destination address packets detected

discovery_rules.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rules.description: The discovery of different types of file systems as defined in the global regular expression "File systems for discovery".

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Free disk space is less than 20%

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Filesystem is read-only
item_prototypes.description: The filesystem is mounted as read-only. It is available only for Zabbix agents 6.4 and higher.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Filesystem has become read-only
trigger_prototypes.description: The filesystem has become read-only. A possible reason is an I/O error. It is available only for Zabbix agents 6.4 and higher.

overrides.name: Skip metadata collection for dynamic FS

macros.description: The timeout after which the agent is considered unavailable. It works only for the agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (in passive mode).
regex to skip trigger creation for counters
Packets with incorrect IP fragment offsets.
TCP timestamps that are suspicious or invalid.
Packets dropped due to congestion (e.g., queue full).
Packets that failed to map through a NAT rule (address pool exhausted or invalid).
Packets dropped due to memory allocation failure in pf.
Packets that were normalized (e.g., header reordering, timestamp clearing).
Packets too short to be valid (likely malformed).
Packets dropped because the source node hit a configured limit (e.g., max-src-conn).
Packets that attempted to create a new state but failed due to rules.
Packets dropped due to global state table limits being reached.
Packets that don’t match an expected state (out-of-sync connection).
SYN packets that were intercepted and verified with SYN proxy.

fields.name: ds.0.items.0
fields.value: *:in:USER_RULE: Default allow LAN to any rule -  bits*
